analysis:
Here are the answers to the questions based on the ecosystem data:

**1. What repetitive tasks across projects can be automated?**

* Automated project health checks: scrape Notion, send summaries
	+ Problem: Manual effort in tracking and summarizing project progress
	+ Tools/Tech needed: Web scraping tools (e.g., Cheerio), email sending tools (e.g., Mailgun)
	+ Implementation effort: Medium (requires development of a web scraper and email sender)
	+ Obsolescence support: As projects become self-sufficient, automated health checks ensure ACT's role is reduced to advisory
* AI-powered relationship suggestions: Gmail + CRM data
	+ Problem: Manual effort in identifying connections between projects
	+ Tools/Tech needed: Email API (e.g., Gmail), CRM integration tools (e.g., Zapier)
	+ Implementation effort: Low (requires configuration of APIs and integrations)
	+ Obsolescence support: As organizations become self-sufficient, AI-powered suggestions help them identify new connections independently

**2. What data/insights can be automatically collected and shared?**

* Collective impact dashboards: automated metric aggregation
	+ Problem: Manual effort in tracking and aggregating metrics across projects
	+ Tools/Tech needed: Data aggregation tools (e.g., Google Data Studio), dashboard creation tools (e.g., Tableau)
	+ Implementation effort: High (requires development of data pipelines and dashboard design)
	+ Obsolescence support: As organizations become self-sufficient, collective impact dashboards provide a single source of truth for their metrics
* Knowledge base automation: capture learnings from emails/meetings
	+ Problem: Manual effort in documenting lessons learned from projects
	+ Tools/Tech needed: Email analysis tools (e.g., Mailchimp), meeting note-taking tools (e.g., Otter)
	+ Implementation effort: Medium (requires configuration of email and meeting note-taking integrations)
	+ Obsolescence support: As organizations become self-sufficient, knowledge base automation helps them capture and apply learnings independently

**3. What connections/introductions can be systematically suggested?**

* Collaborative opportunity detection: match projects on outcomes
	+ Problem: Manual effort in identifying potential collaborations between projects
	+ Tools/Tech needed: Matching algorithm tools (e.g., GitHub Copilot), project outcome tracking tools (e.g., Notion)
	+ Implementation effort: High (requires development of a matching algorithm and integration with project outcome tracking)
	+ Obsolescence support: As organizations become self-sufficient, collaborative opportunity detection helps them identify new partners independently

**4. What reporting/tracking can be automated?**

* Automated project status updates: send regular summaries to stakeholders
	+ Problem: Manual effort in updating stakeholders on project progress
	+ Tools/Tech needed: Email sending tools (e.g., Mailgun), project tracking tools (e.g., Trello)
	+ Implementation effort: Medium (requires configuration of email sender and integration with project tracking tool)
	+ Obsolescence support: As organizations become self-sufficient, automated project status updates ensure stakeholders are informed independently

**5. How can AI assist in relationship management at scale?**

* AI-powered relationship suggestions: analyze CRM data and suggest connections
	+ Problem: Manual effort in identifying new relationships between projects
	+ Tools/Tech needed: AI/ML tools (e.g., Google Cloud AI Platform), CRM integration tools (e.g., Zapier)
	+ Implementation effort: High (requires development of an AI-powered recommendation engine and integration with CRM data)
	+ Obsolescence support: As organizations become self-sufficient, AI-powered relationship suggestions help them identify new connections independently
